awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites:  Type II - Purdue University I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project from Purdue University that extends its already existing I-Corps Site for the next phase of expansion of their services that support innovation and entrepreneurship. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. 

A renewed Purdue I-Corps Site award enables Purdue to build on their accomplishments from their first three years and maintain momentum while: funding 30+ faculty and student teams annually; increasing the number of national I-Corps teams from the College of Engineering; increasing support for and participation by women entrepreneurs; expanding support for selective undergraduate senior design teams; and increasing engagement with State of Indiana's economic development agencies as well as the regional entrepreneurial ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
From 2018-2022, Purdue I-Corps Site was a major contributor to Purdue?s success in commercializing university developed IP. A report prepared by IPWatchdog Institute covering an 11-year period of technology commercialization activities lists Purdue University third in the U.S. for startup creation. Purdue?s land grant mission includes a commitment to converting life-changing technologies to the market that create new jobs, new opportunities, and new ways to positively impact our global society. In addition to enabling the translation of Purdue technology from the lab to the market, the Site programs have helped instill an entrepreneurial mindset in faculty and graduate researchers and has provided researchers with the the tools to plan and conduct use-inspired research. 

 

Highlights of the impact of the I-Corps Site award include

  • Four hundred and forty-four (444) faculty and graduate students have participated in Purdue?s I-Corps programs and graduate courses, representing over 150 teams.
  • During the period of the Type ll award, 33 Purdue teams have been accepted into the National I-Corps Teams program, plus 4 teams from other universities who participated in our I-Corps Site program.
  • Reaching to all academic disciplines has been a priority for the I-Corps Site. National I-Corps teams have come from a variety of disciplines include Chemical Engineering, Purdue Polytechnic Institute, Engineering Education, Medicinal Chemistry and Molecular Biology, Pharmacy, Speech Pathology, Agriculture & Biological Engineering (ABE), Mechanical Engineering, Aeronautics & Astronautics, Biomedical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Materials Engineering, Physics, Veterinary Medicine, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Civil Engineering, Engineering Education, Management, Computer Science, Agronomy, Forestry and Natural Resources, Aeronautics & Astronautics, Chemistry, Education, and Industrial Engineering.
  • Participation in the I-Corps is a pathway to PFI-TT and SBIR commercialization awards. Purdue teams who have participated in the National I-Corps Teams program have experienced greater than a 90% success rate when applying for these commercialization awards.
  • As a result of our efforts to reach out to female faculty and graduate students, 40% of participants in our I-Corps Site and I-Corps teams programs are women, compared with 25% female faculty and graduate students in the College of Engineering.
  • The I-Corps methodology has become the standard approach across Purdue's campus for design, innovation, and entrepreneurship courses. I-Corps teaching materials have been disseminated in entrepreneurship, design, innovation, and capstone courses in the College of Engineering and the Purdue Polytechnic Institute as well programs run by the Burton Morgan Center for Entrepreneurship, including business competitions, and the faculty Entrepreneurial Learning Academy.

The Type ll award enabled the sustainability of the I-Corps program beyond the period of funding, both through internally funded and institutionalized programming and as a member of the I-Corps Hub, Great Lakes Region.

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2023
Modified by: Matthew Lynall

From 2018-2022, Purdue I-Corps Site was a major contributor to Purdue?s success in commercializing university developed IP. A report prepared by IPWatchdog Institute covering an 11-year period of technology commercialization activities lists Purdue University third in the U.S. for startup creation. Purdue?s land grant mission includes a commitment to converting life-changing technologies to the market that create new jobs, new opportunities, and new ways to positively impact our global society. In addition to enabling the translation of Purdue technology from the lab to the market, the Site programs have helped instill an entrepreneurial mindset in faculty and graduate researchers and has provided researchers with the the tools to plan and conduct use-inspired research. 

 

Highlights of the impact of the I-Corps Site award include

Four hundred and forty-four (444) faculty and graduate students have participated in Purdue?s I-Corps programs and graduate courses, representing over 150 teams.
During the period of the Type ll award, 33 Purdue teams have been accepted into the National I-Corps Teams program, plus 4 teams from other universities who participated in our I-Corps Site program.
Reaching to all academic disciplines has been a priority for the I-Corps Site. Participation in the I-Corps is a pathway to PFI-TT and SBIR commercialization awards. Purdue teams who have participated in the National I-Corps Teams program have experienced greater than a 90% success rate when applying for these commercialization awards.
As a result of our efforts to reach out to female faculty and graduate students, 40% of participants in our I-Corps Site and I-Corps teams programs are women, compared with 25% female faculty and graduate students in the College of Engineering.
The I-Corps methodology has become the standard approach across Purdue's campus for design, innovation, and entrepreneurship courses. The Type ll award enabled the sustainability of the I-Corps program beyond the period of funding, both through internally funded and institutionalized programming and as a member of the I-Corps Hub, Great Lakes Region.
